page.title: 02BUILDINGS AND MATERIALS
page.content: As the area was originally forest, it is not surprising to find that wood has played a large part in the construction of the local houses. Most of the houses built before 1930 are timber frame with lathe and plaster walls. Roofing is either pantiles or thatch with a brick chimney either built centrally or on one end wall. The advent of the railway enabled stone and brick to be used more widely in the area and since the 1930's with much easier transport, brick has taken over as the dominant material used in house construction although we have seen wood making a comeback in recent times. {It is interesting to note that the {local churches contain some Roman {stone which has been recovered from {the old Roman Stane Street which {originally ran nearby.
